content: The Act aims to improve the codification of title 46, United States Code, by incorporating public comments and amendments made after the cutoff date specified in the bill. It specifically addresses personal injury to or death of seamen. Section 30104 of title 46, United States Code is amended to allow a seaman injured in the course of employment to bring an action under US laws similar to those for railway employees. The action can be in admiralty or as an action at law with trial by jury, and venue is determined by the plaintiff's choice. The venue for legal action by a seaman injured in the course of employment is determined by the plaintiff's choice. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO CHAPTER 537. Amendments to Chapter 537 include redesignating paragraphs, defining terms like Administrator and Secretary, and setting priorities for certain vessels in title 46, United States Code. Amendments to Chapter 537 in title 46, United States Code set priorities for certain vessels in guaranteeing obligations under the Maritime Security Act of 2003. Vessels constructed with assistance under subtitle D are given priority, followed by vessels suitable for naval service as determined by the Secretary of Defense. The Secretary of Defense determines if a vessel is suitable for naval service in times of war or national emergency and meets sealift capacity needs within 30 days of a request from the Administrator. Section 53707 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to include the Administrator in certain subsections. Section 53708 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to replace references to the Secretary of Transportation with the Administrator. Section 51504(f) is amended to specify that the Secretary will pay for fuel costs for vessels used by State maritime academies for training, with a maximum payment limit. The funding limit for maritime academies is set at $100,000 for fiscal year 2006, $200,000 for fiscal year 2007, and $300,000 for fiscal year 2008 onwards.
